description: Originally the same word as scuffle, and properly a frequentative of shove.

examples: He made a real mess of the last shuffle.

entries.meaning: The act of reordering anything, such as music tracks in a media player.
An instance of walking without lifting one's feet.
examples: The sad young girl left with a tired shuffle.

entries.meaning: (by extension, music) A rhythm commonly used in blues music. Consists of a series of triplet notes with the middle note missing, so that it sounds like a long note followed by a short note. Sounds like a walker dragging one foot.
(dance) A dance move in which the foot is scuffed across the floor back and forth.
A trick; an artifice; an evasion.

verbs.description: shuffle (third-person singular simple present shuffles, present participle shuffling, simple past and past participle shuffled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To put in a random order.
examples: Don't forget to shuffle the cards.
The data packets are shuffled before transmission.
I'm going to shuffle all the songs in my playlist.

entries.meaning: To change; modify the order of something.
(transitive, intransitive) To move in a slovenly, dragging manner; to drag or scrape the feet in walking or dancing.
examples: He shuffled out of the room.
I shuffled my feet in embarrassment.

entries.meaning: To change one's position; to shift ground; to evade questions; to resort to equivocation; to prevaricate.
To use arts or expedients; to make shift.
To shove one way and the other; to push from one to another.
examples: to shuffle money from hand to hand

entries.meaning: To remove or introduce by artificial confusion.
